question: A 42-year-old woman was diagnosed with metastatic cervical cancer. Cervical cancers are mostly associated with human papillomavirus infections, which are now preventable with the help of vaccines. This vaccine is made up of which of the following?

answers.option: A mix of live and killed vaccines

question: A 32-year-old plumber developed pneumonia and was in the hospital for a week. The sputum was sent for culture and sensitivity. Laboratory reports showed Gram-positive cocci arranged in clusters. What is the causative organism?

A 45-year-old patient presented to the clinic with a postoperative surgical site infection after an emergency laparotomy. The sample was pus collected in a sterile syringe and sent to the laboratory for routine culture and sensitivity. Gram-stain revealed Gram-positive cocci in clusters with numerous pus cells. After 24 hours, beta-hemolytic colonies grew on the sheep blood agar plate, which was coagulase and catalase positive. What is the most likely causative agent?

A 15-year-old girl was brought to the emergency unit by her mother with complaints of sudden fever, headache, and stiff neck. Other symptoms were nausea, vomiting, increased sensitivity to light, and confusion. Cerebrospinal fluid was sent to the laboratory for routine culture and a detailed report. Microscopic examination showed diplococci organisms. Growth revealed grey colonies, which were catalase negative. Which of the following bacteria is most probably causing infection?

Several vaccines are prepared using different bacterial components. Sometimes after vaccinating the population, vaccine-escape variants emerge. The most often component used in the development of bacterial vaccines is which of the following?
Myc gene is implicated in which disorder?
A 32-year-old patient develops fever and myalgia. The physician orders a complete blood count (CBC). In case of a viral illness, the CBC will show an increase in which of the following?

A young boy suffered from multiple infections. Family history was suggestive of antibody deficiency. His complete blood picture showed normal levels of T and B lymphocytes, however, serum immunoglobulin levels were markedly low. Which antibodies can activate the complement system?
25-year-old sexually active woman complaint of greenish-yellow vaginal discharge. Culture shows Gram-negative diplococci. What is the causative agent?
What is the main aim to perform an autopsy?

answers.option: To look for any possible injuries
To identify the cause of death
To look for signs of life

question: What is the demerit of arsenic as an ideal homicidal poison?

answers.option: It is toxic in large doses

question: An ideal homicidal poison should be which of the following:
Gastric lavage is contraindicated in which of the following poisoning?
If water is used for gastric lavage, preferably it should be which of the following?
What is the treatment of choice for lead poisoning?
What is the ideal position of patient while performing gastric lavage?
What does the sympathetic stimulation of the iris cause?
In the division of the autonomic system, from where do parasympathetic fibers originate?
Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding pilocarpine?

answers.option: Duration of action is about 1 hour
Drug of choice for emergency lowering intraocular pressure
It is an alkaloid in nature

question: Which statement is not correct about bethanechol?

answers.option: Structurally consists of carbamate and methylated choline
Duration of action is about 1 hour
More specific for muscarinic receptors than nicotinic

question: Which of the following does forensic medicine not deal with?

A 45-year-old female developed a fever with burning micturition. She was diagnosed with having urinary tract infection. The growth on the blood agar showed swarming organisms. Other chemical tests were performed. Gram-negative, non-spore-forming, oxidase-negative, non-lactose fermenting, H₂S-producing rod-shaped bacteria were isolated. Infection in the urinary tract may occur with indwelling catheters. Which organism is isolated in this patient?
A 42-year-old patient was suspected of having tuberculosis. Microscopy showed acid-fast bacilli. What will be the medium of choice for the culture of these bacteria?
Which of the following diseases is inherited in an X-linked recessive fashion?
Tumor-associated antigens are antigens present on the surface of the tumor cells. What is true for these antigens?

answers.option: Are always specific for specific tumors
Only develop in tumors induced by viruses
Can be recognized as non-self antigens

question: Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) causes a reduction of T cell count to a level where the patient becomes severely deficient. HIV preferentially attacks which of the following?
HLA-DR2 is a risk factor for which of the following?
A number of diseases are detected through antigen-antibody reactions. Which test utilizes this mechanism?

A toxoid is an inactivated toxin that has lost its ability to cause disease but has retained its immunogenicity. The vaccines against which of these bacterial infections contains toxoid as an antigen?
Regarding the oncogene of DNA tumor viruses, which of the following is most accurate?

answers.option: They encode protein kinase that phosphorylates p53 protein
They encode cellular growth factors that activates S-phase DNA synthesis
They encode proteins that bind to the proteins coded by tumor suppressor genes
They encode muscular growth factors that activates G-phase DNA synthesis
They interact with cellular proto-oncogenes and activates them

question: While reading the antimicrobial susceptibility results, the technologist noticed gaps in the growth of bacteria. Viruses that infect and kill the bacteria resemble the lunar lander and are composed of polyhedral heads, helical bodies, and legs that attach to the cell membrane so that they can transfer their genetic material. Bacteriophage belongs to which of the following classes of virus?
Tumor cells have several different mechanisms. These cells are mainly targeted by the T cells of the body. What is the function of the T cells?

answers.option: Activate humoral immunity against cancer cells
Secrete perforins that create pores in the membrane of target cells
Secrete lipid that stimulate growth and activation of both B and T cells

question: A 25-year-old woman has had several severe episodes of pneumonia in the past 5 months. She has not had frequent or unusual infections before the onset of this pneumonia. Which of the following is the most likely immunodeficiency that predisposes her to these infections?

answers.option: Mutation in the gene that encodes the C3a portion of the complement
Defect in cytotoxic T cells function
Mutation in one of the gene that encode the class Ⅰ MHC proteins

question: A 7-year-old boy presented in the outpatient department with complaints of malaise and lethargy for the last 10 days. He had become inattentive at school, anorexic, and lost 4 kg weight in the last 2 years. On examination, he was thin, anxious, and clinically anemic and also has moderate hepatosplenomegaly. The physician was suspecting a malignant etiology for all these complaints. Which cells are predominantly mediated in antitumor activity?

A 3rd-year medical student attends a night-long educational retreat and develops a cough and fever. Several different attendees are sick with similar symptoms. Public health officials studying the outbreak suspect contaminated air-conditioning. What could be the cause?

A 79-year-old man with end-stage Alzheimer's disease and dysphagia is taking multiple medications. Physical examination reveals xerostomia and a limited gag reflex. Which of the following routes of medication administration would provide the lowest serum drug concentrations?

A 28-year-old man with seborrheic dermatitis is prescribed a topical corticosteroid cream by his dermatologist in hopes of alleviating the chronic rash and erythema on the cheeks. Which of the following steps is most critical to achieving a therapeutic drug concentration in plasma?
What is the advantage of a drug administered subcutaneously?

answers.option: Can be given when patient is in shock

question: What happens to a drug after the addition of glucuronic acid to it?

answers.option: Leads to inactivation of the drug
Its an example of phase I reaction
Occurs at the same rate in adults and newborns

question: Which of the following is the most important action of drug metabolism?

answers.option: Increase binding of drug to plasma protein
Increase drug availability at receptor site

question: Which organ is responsible for the majority of drug excretion?

A 16-year-old girl suffering from seasonal rhinitis started therapy with loratadine, a drug that binds H1 histamine receptors. Which of the following terms best defines the intrinsic ability of a drug to bind to a receptor?
Why is antagonism between adrenaline and histamine called physiological antagonism?

answers.option: Both are physiologically present in the body

question: Which receptor type has 7 helical membrane spanning amino acid segments intracellular loops?
If a patient comes with a complain of nasal stuffiness, what would be the drug of choice?
Which of the following features is not present in an ideal homicidal poison?

answers.option: Symptoms should resemble a natural disease

question: Some viruses cause the downregulation of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) I complex to evade CD8 cells. Which of the following immune cells are involved in killing such cells with downregulated MHC I?
